When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves above a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return to the original place), it often finds itself in a different environment than that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they won't be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

The technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense that the fate of humanity is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself occurs beyond the cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The possession of a large number of cars also leads to an increase in road accidents, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat bodily injuries.

On September 17, 1939, the Polish defense was already broken, and the only hope was to retreat and reorganize along the Romanian front.

The use of ships for transporting goods is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across oceans.

The work of the Marines has traditionally been to ensure that your country retains the ability to move your people and goods, while interfering with the ability of your enemy to move his people and goods.

One of the most recent and remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic campaign during World War II. The Americans tried to make it possible for soldiers and equipment to cross the Atlantic Ocean to help the British.
At the same time, the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have been able to conquer Britain as it did for the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains in Iran.
The ancient cultures and tribes started keeping them close to them to have easy access to milk, hair, meat and skins.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that wandered on the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more well-known term of shepherds. These pastoral methods have always been in use today.
The "wagonways" were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the tracks were simply wooden planks laid parallel to each other, they allowed horses pulling them to reach higher speeds and to carry heavier loads than on the slightly more uneven roads of the day.
The crossbeams were introduced fairly early to keep the tracks in place. However, it soon became apparent that the tracks would be more effective if they were fitted with a strip of iron on top.
This has become a common practice, but iron caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: humans began to walk upright two million years ago with the arrival of Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopithecines, did not walk upright as usual.
Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus could walk on two legs seven million years ago.

In many cases, it is a symptomatic treatment. However, if we don't want a temporary solution, we must find the root of the problems and deactivate them.

It is clear that the world has changed greatly due to the scientific and technological progress made by humans, and that the problems have become more important due to the overpopulation and extravagant lifestyle of humanity.

After its adoption by the Congress on 4 July, a manuscript signed by the President of Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as Dunlap Broadsides.
The first public reading of the document took place in the hall of the Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap leaves still known to exist are the oldest copies of the document. The original manuscript copy has not survived.
Many palaeontologists think that a group of dinosaurs survived and is still alive. They are called birds.
Very few people consider them dinosaurs because they have wings and can fly.
But there are lots of things about birds that still look like dinosaurs.
They are covered with scales and have claws, they lay eggs and walk on their hind legs like T-Rexes.
Practically all computers used today are based on manipulating information that is coded in binary numbers.
A binary number can only have one of two values: 0 or 1. These numbers are called binary numbers, or bits for using the computer jargon.
Internal poisoning may not be immediately visible. Symptoms, such as vomiting, are sufficiently general to make an immediate diagnosis impossible.
The best indicator of internal poisoning is probably the presence of an open container of drugs or household chemicals.
Consult the label for specific first aid instructions for this poison.
The term "insect" is used by entomologists in a formal sense for this group of insects.
This term derives from an old familiarity with bed bugs, which are very well adapted to parasitize humans.
Redworms, just like bed bugs, are nidicolous, that is, adapted to live in the nest or the habitat of their host.
In the United States, there are about 400,000 known cases of multiple sclerosis (MS), which makes it the most common neurological disease in young and middle-aged adults.
Multiple sclerosis is a disease that affects the central nervous system, composed of the brain, spinal cord and optic nerve.
Research has shown that women are twice as likely to have multiple sclerosis as men.
A couple may very well feel that it is not in their interest, nor in the interest of the child, to care for a baby.
These couples can choose to do an adoption project for their baby.
In the context of adoption, the biological parents end their parental rights so that another couple can raise the child.

Many rhythms observed in physiology and behavior often depend on the presence of endogenous cycles and their production by biological clocks.
Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to external periodic stimuli, have been documented for most living things, including bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that will continue to operate for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.
The Hershey-Chase experiment was one of the main indications that DNA was a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to label either the phage DNA with radioactive phosphorus or the phage protein with radioactive sulfur.
Mutations can have many different effects depending on the type of mutation, the part of the genetic material affected and whether the affected cells are germ cells.
Only germ cell mutations can be transmitted to children, while other mutations can lead to cell death or cancer.
Ecotourism interests people who want to visit natural areas in order to enjoy the scenery, especially the fauna and flora.
Hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, visiting parks and studying information on the ecosystem are examples of on-site activities.
One can, for example, go to see, photograph and discover orang-utans in Borneo.
Every morning, people leave the small towns of the countryside in their cars to go to work and cross other people who are going to work in the countryside they just left.
In this dynamic transport shuttle, each is in some way connected to a transport system based on private cars and support.
Science now shows that this massively carbon-based economy has displaced the biosphere from its state of stability that has supported human evolution for two million years.
Everyone is part of society and uses transport systems. Almost everyone complains about transport systems.
In developed countries, it is rare to hear so many complaints about the quality of water or the collapse of bridges.
Why do transportation systems generate such complaints, why do they break down daily? Are transportation engineers simply incompetent? Or is there something more fundamental going on?
Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and private vehicles between two points, and of the interactions they exert between themselves.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because drivers' behavior cannot be predicted with a hundred percent certainty.
Unfortunately, drivers tend to act within a reasonably consistent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonably consistent coherence and can be approximated mathematically.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) flow, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relationships help to plan, design, and operate road facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape more easily from their enemies and to find more efficiently food and companions.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their bodies.
It gives them more places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that can't fold their wings are dragonflies and ephemera.
About a thousand years ago, a man named Aristarque claimed that the solar system moves around the Sun.
Some thought he was right, but many believed the opposite: that the solar system moved around the Earth, including the Sun (and even the other stars).
It seems reasonable, because the Earth doesn't seem to move, doesn't it?
The Amazon River is the second-longest and largest river on Earth. It carries more than eight times the volume of water of the second-largest river.
The Amazon is also the world's largest river, sometimes reaching 10 km in width.
Not less than 20 percent of the water that pours into the oceans from rivers on the planet comes from the Amazon.
The main branch of the Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles) long. It collects water from thousands of small rivers.

The Vatican has about 800 residents. It is the smallest independent country in the world, and the least populated.
The Vatican City State drafts its legislation and official communications in Italian.
Italian is also the everyday language used by most people who work in the state, while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies.
The citizens of the Vatican City are all Roman Catholics.

The thickness of the crust is about 70 km on the visible side and 100 km on the hidden side.
It is thinner at the seas and thicker under continents.

Content theories are centered on the search for what makes people feel good or attractive.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that have been internalized as they mature toward adulthood.
These theories examine what drives some people to want things they do and what, in their environment, drives them to do or not do certain things.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
In general, two behaviors can emerge when a manager becomes the boss of former colleagues. On one end of the spectrum is trying to remain the good friend (or the good friend).
This type of manager has a hard time taking unpopular decisions, leading disciplinary actions, conducting evaluations, assigning responsibilities, and holding others accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels that he or she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things his/her own way.
After all, the leader is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behaviour often leads to disagreements between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet in different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "hidden team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the management team to which each member reports. It sets standards for each of them.

Before an organization is innovative, its management must create an innovation culture, shared knowledge and its own learning culture.

Neuro-biological data provide material evidence for a theoretical approach to the study of cognition. They therefore reduce the scope of research and make it much more precise.
The correlation between brain pathology and behavior supports scientists in their research.

The rise of new technologies allows us to see and study brain structures and processes that have never been seen before.

Although artificial intelligence is often strongly associated with science fiction, it represents a very important part of computer science which studies the behaviour, learning and intelligent adaptation of a machine.
Artificial intelligence research aims at automating tasks requiring intelligent approaches.
Among the examples are control, planning and programming, the ability to respond to diagnostics and questions of clients, as well as recognition of writing, voice and face.
These practices have led to distinct disciplines, focused on the contribution of solutions to everyday problems.
The AI system is now often used in fields such as economics, medicine, engineering and the military, as it has been used in several home computer and video game software.
Excursions are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

The solution is brought about by technology in the form of virtual educational outings. Students can look at old objects in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful artwork while sitting with their class.
Practically participating in an excursion is also a great way to think about a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students at Bennet College in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the capital of the state. Each year, the website is updated, but the old versions are kept online as an album.

Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even if students often try the blogging experience with a neglected grammar and spelling, the fact of having a public audience usually makes the situation evolve.
As students are often the most critical audience, the author of the blog begins to strive to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
Moreover, blogging "obliges students to better understand the world around them". The need to attract the public's interest encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used properly, blogs can allow students to strengthen their analytical and critical capacities: by actively reacting to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own points of view on specific topics."
Ottawa is the charming bilingual capital of Canada and boasts a large number of art galleries and museums that highlight the past and present of Canada.
You will find more south the Niagara Falls and north, the Muskoka region and its surroundings which have a natural beauty unspoiled.
These measures, and many others, make Ontario what foreigners consider to be the quintessence of Canada.
Large areas further north are sparsely populated and some are almost uninhabited in the wild.

Madagascar is by far the largest country, and even a continent on its own, in terms of wildlife.
Most of the small islands are independent nations, or associated with France, and are known for being luxury resorts.
The Arabs also brought Islam to the land and this religion has widely spread to the Comoros and Mayotte.
European influence and colonialism began in the 15th century, when Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama discovered the Cape route that links Europe to India.
To the north, the region is bounded by the Sahel, and to the south and to the west by the Atlantic Ocean.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 9th century BC, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and the Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who after it had been destroyed had rebuilt it and named it Casa Branca, abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tajines, pottery, leather goods, narguilés and all kinds of trinkets, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in the eastern portion of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano which buried most of the city's streets, especially the downtown.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma must be researched to understand the state of the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the Nyiragongo Volcano as well as for gorilla tracking treks among the cheapest in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorbike taxi) to move around Goma. The normal price (local) is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative remoteness, "Tombouctou" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.
Today, Tombouctou is a poor city, though its reputation makes it a tourist attraction, and it has an airport.
In 1990, it was added to the list of World Heritage sites at risk, due to the threat of sand dunes.
It was one of the main steps of the show "Wonders of the African World" of Henry Louis Gates on PBS.
The town contrasts sharply with the cities of the rest of the country, as it has a style more Arab than African.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and runs along the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the southern border is the Crocodile River.
The total surface of the park is 19,500 km2, which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which harbours a specific fauna.
It is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered the crown jewel of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entry and conservation fees for the park.
It can be advantageous to purchase a Wild Card which gives access to some South African parks, as well as all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and represents the main attraction for many tourists.
The line of skyscrapers that defines the horizon of Hong Kong has been compared to a scintillating bar graph, which reveals itself by reflection in the waters of Victoria Harbour.
To admire the most beautiful panoramas of Hong Kong, leave the island and join the Kowloon frontier located on the opposite side.
The majority of urban development on Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the north bank landfill sites.
It is the place that the British colonists have invested. So it seems like a good starting point if you are looking for evidence of colonialism in this region.
The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove belt in the world, stretching over 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the Bangladeshi and Indian backwaters.
The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Indian part of the forest is called the Sundarbans National Park.
However, forests are not composed only of mangrove swamps. They also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which about one third is covered by water/marshy areas.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Royal Bengal Tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The buses leave the intercity bus station (on the other side of the river) throughout the day, but most, particularly those that serve east and Jakar/Bumthang, leave between 6:30 and 7:30 in the morning.
Inter-district buses are often full, so it is advised to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most districts are served by small Japanese boats, which are comfortable and robust.
Collective taxis are a quick and comfortable way to get to places nearby, such as Paro (150 Nu) and Punakha (200 Nu).
The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It overhangs the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers are 83 metres high; it is 378 metres long and has two 3.5 metre wide lanes.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 metres. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was opened to traffic in March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guarani were the most important indigenous group inhabiting what is now the east of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes who inhabited the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay was born from the meeting between Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the colonial period, which lasted three centuries.
Since the foundation of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has managed to preserve a large part of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is known for having one of the best teams and among the best polo players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on the polo fields of Las Cañitas.
In addition, tournaments and smaller-scale matches are sometimes organised here at other times of the year.
For information on polo tournaments and where to buy tickets for polo matches, visit the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP) which is equivalent to one pound sterling (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank in the Cook Islands located in Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a widely accepted currency in the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and U.S. dollars are also often accepted.
On the nearby islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if British and American currency may be accepted. Talk to the owners ahead of time to agree on a method of payment.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.
Montevideo being located south of Ecuador, winter in the northern hemisphere corresponds to summer there and vice versa.
Montevideo is located in the subtropical zone and summer temperatures exceeding 30 °C are common.
Winter can be deceivingly cold: the temperatures rarely fall below zero, but the wind and humidity combine to give the impression that it is colder than the thermometer says.
There is no "rainy season" or "dry season". Rainfall is fairly constant throughout the year.
Though many of the animals in the park are used to seeing humans, they are wild animals; please do not feed them or disturb them.
According to the authorities of the park, it is necessary to be at least 100 metres away from bears and wolves and 25 metres away from all other wild animals.
As docile as they may seem, the bison, the elk, the moose, the bear and almost all large animals can attack.
Each year, dozens of visitors are injured because they did not keep enough distance. These animals are large, wild and potentially dangerous, so give them space.
In addition, know that odors attract bears and other wild animals, so avoid carrying or cooking odorous foods and keep the camp clean.
Apia is the capital of Samoa. The city is located on the island of Upolu and has about 40,000 inhabitants.
Apia was founded in the 1850s and is the official capital of Samoa since 1959.

All ships were sunk, except a British cruiser. Nearly 200 Americans and Germans lost their lives.
The Supreme Chief Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III was assassinated during a peaceful rally in the city, during the struggle for independence organized by the Mau movement.
Beaches are numerous, because Auckland is on two harbours. The most popular are in three areas.
The North Shore beaches (in the North Harbour district) are on the Pacific Ocean and stretch from Long Bay to the north to Devonport to the south.
Most beaches are sandy and allow safe swimming, and most are shaded by pohutukawa.
Tamaki Drive beaches are located on the Waitemata Harbour, in the chic Mission Bay and Saint Heliers neighbourhoods of Auckland.
These beaches, sometimes very popular with families, have many shops along the coastline. Swimming is safe here.

A walking safari (also known as bushwalking, walking safari or footing) is a form of hiking, either for a few hours or for several days.

Infectious diseases themselves, or dangerous animals that can injure or kill people by force, are generally not considered parasites.

Travellers to countries where taxes are high can sometimes save a lot of money, especially on products like alcohol and tobacco.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has one foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth and narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, especially English saddles, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if it is pulled back by a rider who falls.
